issues.title: Remove Werror compiler flag
issues.body:
It's generally considered bad practice to ship software with this flag.
Issue revealed while updating the port on [OpenBSD].

[OpenBSD]: https://marc.info/?l=openbsd-ports&m=151482370923381&w=2

issues.title: Sanbox support for more operating systems
issues.body:
It would be interesting to investigate adding support for sandboxing on
operating systems other than OpenBSD where [pledge] is available.
There's seccomp on Linux and Capsicum on FreeBSD. I wouldn't worry about
the portability at this stage, just the code required to get it working
would be a great start.

[pledge]: http://man.openbsd.org/pledge

issues.title: Create a pick Recipes page, maybe as part of the Wiki
issues.body:
`pick` is really awesome, in less than a month it's become a great friend to me. It makes working with git branches and commits a lot easier, but maybe I wouldn't have thought to use it like that if I hadn't seen the gif in the README.

My point is that pick is a versatile tool whose possibilities aren't necessarily obvious at first. I think having a Wiki-style section for Recipes could bring in creative, cool use cases, and give new users more ideas of how to use pick.

I wrote [a post](http://kylebebak.github.io/post/git-utility-functions-pick) about how I use it with git, I basically wrote some [helper functions](https://github.com/kylebebak/dotfiles/blob/master/dotfiles/.helpers/pick.sh) that wrap pick to make operations with branches and commits very fast.

This is the kind of stuff I think could go into Recipes, snippets of code using pick and gifs showing them in action. If this seems like a good idea I would love to contribute.

issues.title: Stream input
issues.body: pick must read its input entirely before the filtering interface becomes responsive. For an example, in a directory with a large number of entries (say > 150,000), compare `find . -type f | pick`, which will take at least seconds to become responsive, and `find . -type f | less`, which is immediately responsive. [fzf](https://github.com/junegunn/fzf) is one example of a fuzzy finder that handles this well by searching over entries received so far and streaming in new entries as they match.

commit.message: Update release notes
Update version to 2.0.1
Update CHANGELOG
Update release notes
Remove a cast since tparm takes a non-const char pointer

travis: execute script in a subshell enabling errexit and xtrace

Enabling errexit on Travis could interfere with their scripts, therefore
use a subshell. The xtrace option makes debugging easier.

Simplify logic used to determine when choices must be re-displayed

Enabling dofilter implies dochoices by now. Therefore, there's no longer
necessary to fiddle with dochoices for each key binding that doesn't
result in filtering of the choices.

Ensure correctness while typing a query fast

Typing a query fast enough to trigger the poll check in filter_choices()
could yield a wrong set of choices. Since filter_choices() is
interrupted, all choices have yet not been examined and potential
matches could still be left unexamined. Calling print_choices() in this
state causes the unexamined choices to never be reconsidered as
potential matches since they will have a score = 0. The solution is to
never call print_choices() if filter_choices() was interrupted.

Problem reported and partial solution provided by Jenz Guenther in
GitHub issue #268.

Bump pick-test timeout

Needed when compiling with the `-coverage' option since it writes
coverage data upon exit. Ideally, the timeout should only be increased
when running under these circumstances. However, the tests finish much
earlier if all is well.

travis: enable codecov.io

Necessary to use the check rather distcheck task since coverage files
will be present causing distcheck to fail.
travis: switch on BUILD_TYPE

Add missing tests for right key

Discovered using lcov:

$ env CFLAGS='-g -O0 -fprofile-arcs -ftest-coverage' CC=gcc ./configure
$ lcov --base-directory . --directory . --zerocounters -q
$ make check
$ lcov --base-directory . --directory . -c -o pick.info
$ mkdir html
$ genhtml -o html pick.info
$ xdg-open html/index.html
Do not use the escape sequence for literal escape

Allow multiple tests per file to actually run

Do not clear the input file after each test run, obvious mistake since
it only allows one tests per file to be executed. My bad, regression
introduced in commit 54b1e43 ("Add toggle sorting key binding").
Update version to 2.0.0
Update CHANGELOG

Only redraw the choices when necessary

Some key bindings only affect the query and unconditionally redrawing
the choices is therefore a wast of time in such scenarios.

Originally proposed by Jenz Guenther in PR #254.
Add toggle sorting key binding

Fix exit code for h option

Surprised to find out that the h option has been broken from the start.

Do not run each test in a separate process

Fixes a severe bug where the exit code was incorrect for failing tests.
Add missing tests
Fix test failure cause bug
Rename tests to match implementation
Cleanup tests

As of OpenBSD 6.2 pick is now available as a package

Unfortunately, 1.9.0 did not make the cut.
Consolidate tests
Allow multiple tests to be specified in a single file
Error out on mandoc style violations
Fix brew runtime error on travis

Rename DEVELOPING.md -> CONTRIBUTING.md

In order to match the conventions defined by GitHub.

Always cause realloc() to reallocate on OpenBSD

Increases the chance of catching dangling pointers.
Lowercase markdown references
Add installation instruction for CRUX
Add Void Linux install instructions

No need to quote the arguments passed to eval

Pointed out by Jenz Guenther in issue #253.

Use eval in example

Otherwise, aliases won't be expanded. Pointed out by Jenz Guenther in
issue #253.

Update usage examples in README

- Quote argument to cd(1) in order to handle directory names including
  spaces

- Import the new example from the manual

Do not ignore return value from mbtowc(3)

Fixes an issue discovered while compiling using GCC 4.7 on Debian 7 by
Jenz Guenther in #255.

Update example in manual

Replace example with a more portable but equally useful one. Proposed by
Jenz Guenther in PR #253.

Initialize variable

In order to silence GCC 2.95 and 4.8.5 on NetBSD. Sure looks like a
false-positive too me. Reported by Jenz Guenther in PR #251.

Low-hanging optimization

If the user didn't add more characters to the query all choices have to
be reconsidered as potential matches. In the opposite scenario, there's
no point in reconsidered all choices again since the ones that didn't
match the previous query will clearly not match the current one due to
the fact that previous query is a left-most substring of the current
one.
Consolidate calls to filter_choices()

Ignore OSC escape sequences

It was brought to my attention that pick didn't handle OSC escape
sequences correctly. Make sure to ignore them while calculating the line
width for each choice and ignore them while matching.
Breakout logic for ignoring escape sequences

Update package information for Ubuntu

Support for Ubuntu 15.10 (Wily Werewolf) ended on July 28, 2016.

Add a couple missing tests

Not covering any new behavior but it increases the test coverage and the
chances of finding bugs/regressions. Discovered using gcov(1).
Fix typo in test case comment

Inline CCEQ macro

Makes pick compile using musl-libc, reported by Michael Gehring in #249.
Add missing break

Update README

- Remove outdated from source installation instructions, we no longer
  use gpg.

- Mention how-to run the latest unstable version

Update release notes

- Add version bump commit message template

- Verify the checksum

- Add mail headers template suitable for use with mutt(1)
Update version number to 1.9.0
Update CHANGELOG
Update release instructions

Add K option to disable toggling of keyboard transmit mode

Useful when running pick from within another interactive program (like
Vim) which does not re-enable keyboard transmit mode after executing an
external program.

Fixes #246.

Explicitly handle control characters

The current SIGINT handler is not considered safe since it invokes
functions that are not considered asynchronous safe[1]. Quoting the
CERT C Coding Standard:

  In general, it is not safe to invoke I/O functions from within signal
  handlers.

Instead, do not turn control characters into signal but instead handle
the relevant ones explicitly. A pleasant side-effect is being able to
test the Ctrl-C error path.

While here, fix the broken suspend/resume behavior by resetting the
initial terminal state prior suspending and re-read it upon resume. I do
actually use suspend/resume while running pick when I forgot to check
something that will affect the choice to select.

[1] https://www.securecoding.cert.org/confluence/display/c/SIG30-C.+Call+only+asynchronous-safe+functions+within+signal+handlers
Add missing paragraphs to examples section in manual

Do not reset yscroll and selection on redraw

While here, unify handling of when the selection goes off screen.

Simplify error handling of tty_putc()

The error handling can be done inside tty_putc() even tho it's used as
the putfunc argument to tputs() since the latter does not rely on
getting EOF back. Quoting POSIX[1]:

  The user-supplied function putfunc (specified as an argument to
  tputs()) is either putchar() or some other function with the same
  prototype. The tputs() function ignores the return value of putfunc.

[1] http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/7908799/xcurses/putp.html

Add Gentoo install instructions to README

Fixes #243.

Fix broken INSTALL.md.in path while running `make distcheck`

The distcheck target ensures that the distribution tarball is
self-contained, i.e. using only the files present in the distribution it
can create another identical distribution[1]. While doing so, we can't
assume that the current directory is the top-level.

[1] https://www.gnu.org/software/automake/manual/automake.html#Checking-the-Distribution

Make obvious use of xmbtowc()

Should have been fixed in commit 1a4888f ("Unify mbtowc() invocation and
error handling").

Consistently use size_t while counting choices

- Since we can have SIZE_T_MAX many choices, don't use plain signed
  integers.

- Make `choices_lines` unsigned to keep it consistent with
  `tty_{columns,lines}` since commit b5fe77f ("Make tty_{columns,lines}
  unsigned").

- Drop (by now) redundant casts to size_t

- Rework some logic in order to prevent doing subtraction on unsigned
  integers since it could result in wrapping.

- Rework the complex loop in print_choices() by keeping the upper bound
  in the loop declaration. The other loop condition is better suited
  inside the body of the loop. This convention is in general a good rule
  of thumb while constructing complex loops.

Fallback to pkg-config while looking for ncurses library

Makes pick build on Gentoo where ncurses and libtinfo are split out, as
discussed in PR #241.
Clarify that the alternate screen is used by default

Improve the semantics of the manual

Don't treat the slash delimiter as part of the key binding.

Wrap macro arguments in parentheses

Found by clang-tidy.
Alternative keys for Ctrl-W and Page-Down
Add clang 5.0 to the build matrix on Travis

Unify mbtowc() invocation and error handling

An abstraction worth performing since we can unify the internal state
reset and there's currently no need to distinguish between the two
scenarios where mbtowc() returns -1 or 0.

Refactor get_key()

Simplify the prototype by only passing a pointer-pointer that will point
to the input buffer upon return.

While here, declare the buffer as unsigned since the signedness of char
can differ between platforms. This issue was also pointed out by Jenz
Guenther in PR #217.

Fix cast

Should have been fixed in commit 7b99e29 ("Use a double for score").

Avoid integer truncation in choicecmp()

If the size of stdin > INT_MAX the returned value from choicecmp() could
end up being truncated. Therefore make sure to only return integer
constants based on the result of the comparisons.

Make tty_{columns,lines} unsigned

Because having negative dimensions doesn't make sense. This is also
consistent with `struct winsize` where both ws_{row,col} are declared as
unsigned.

Also, guard against negative cols and lines terminal capabilities.

Use tty_columns instead of columns while calculating xscroll

Since commit 7cdafc8 ("Add redraw support with respect to TTY
dimensions") tty_columns is the correct and preferred way of obtaining
the number of columns for the current tty.

Recognize alphanumeric and underscore characters as words

This is equivalent to the ALTWERASE algorithm.

Based on previous work done by Jenz Guenther in PR #231 but further
enhanced to support UTF-8.

Update release notes

- Pass verbose option to tar(1)

- Simplify tagging instructions

Don't ignore distribution files

Makes it more convenient to inspect the outcome of `make distcheck`.
Update version number to 1.8.0
Update CHANGELOG

Update release notes

After discussing the release process with @calleerlandsson and
@mike-burns we decided to stop signing releases in order to simplify the
process. Instead, a SHA-256 checksum will be available for the release
tarball.

Favor the shortest match

Instead of unconditionally returning the length of the current match,
make sure the shortest match bubbles up along the recursive call stack.

Note that this bug only occurs when a choice contains multiple instances
of the query and the right-most match is the shortest one. See the
example below including the choice, query, match prior this commit and
after:

Choice       Query  Before       After
aa/åå/aa/aa  aa/aa  aa/åå/aa/aa  aa/åå/aa/aa
                    ^      ^           ^   ^
                    |------|           |---|

Optimize min_match

Instead of advancing to the next character in the string to examine,
move passed the first occurrence of the first character in the query.
This is the only place another potential match could reside.

This is an order of magnitude faster on my machine when the number of
choices with a match is large.
Update CHANGELOG

Favor the shortest left-most match

Prior this commit, aca would be highlighted as opposed of aba:

  echo aba aca | pick -q aa

If the match is longer than the query, the shortest right-most match was
favor due to a bug introduced in commit 97b510a (Optimize min_match).
LEQ should be used since the algorithm is recursive.

Fix underline spill over bug

If the end of the match is greater than the number of columns the
underline attribute will spill over on the next line since it's never
exited. Running the following command before/after applying this commit
highlights the bug:

  for _ in 0 1; do
    jot -n -s '' $(($COLUMNS - 1)) 0 0
    echo ab
  done | pick -q ab

Remove unused autoconf checks

Validating existence of things that hasn't changed since the 80s seems
wasteful. Especially when the types, headers and functions to look for
is out-of-date in respect to what's used by pick.

sense and is therefore kept as is.

Run distcheck in favor of check on Travis CI

In addition to running the test suite (just like the `check` Make
target), the `distcheck` target also takes the following steps to test
the distribution:

- tries to do a `VPATH` build, with the `srcdir` and all its content
  made read-only;
- installs the package in a temporary directory (with `make install`),
  and tries runs the test suite on the resulting installation (with
  `make installcheck`);
- checks that the package can be correctly uninstalled (by `make
  uninstall`) and cleaned (by `make distclean`);
- finally, makes another tarball to ensure the distribution is
  self-contained.

For more info, see https://www.gnu.org/software/automake/manual/html_node/Checking-the-Distribution.html

In order to clarify the used keys in each test case. Comments may be
placed anywhere on a line. This works since a leading comment will be
evaluated to:

1. The `tests/*.t` and `tests/test.sh` were missing in the distribution.
2. The `T_LOG_COMPILER` command could not find the file `tests/test.sh`

Remove usage of save and restore cursor

cursor the appropriate number of lines/columns is easier to follow.

While at it, make the query cursor movement a single operation as
opposed of the current implementation which is linear with the number of
characters in the query.

Discard unrecognized escape sequences

If the user inputs a unrecognized escape sequence longer than the size
of the input buffer, parts of the sequence would end up in the query.

Since the sequence should be ignored, there's no need to put the read
bytes in the input buffer.

Optimize min_match

The min_match function calls itself recursively once a match is found in
order to find the minimal matching substring using the given query.
However, if the length of a match is equal to the length of the query
there's no point in continue the recursion since the left-most match is
favored.

Remove empty lines

Add query option test and fix timing issue

The test spotted a bug related to filter abort introduced in 1ba7398.
The pick-test command enters keyboard input at a very high pace causing
the filtering to be aborted since the input file descriptor contains
unexamined data and 0 mod any number will always equal 0. Therefore,
only abort if at least 50 choices has already been filtered. This is not
a exhaustive solution, consider the following scenario: the number of
choices is greater than 50 and the search is slow, the user inputs any
key that won't affect the query (like choice movement) the filtering
will then be aborted leaving the filtered choices in a bad state. The
correct solution would be to peek at the input file descriptor and only
abort if the first byte is a printable ASCII or UTF-8 character. Such a
solution is complex and this scenario is unlikely to occur.
Add version option test
Print the output from pick-test on failure
Remove redundant braces
Calculate number of available lines once

Add missing test of Vim arrow keys

The test does not hit any new code-path but can be useful for the future
in order to prevent regression.

Cleanup CFLAGS

- Using -pedantic with -Werror has the same effect as -pedantic-errors

- -Wno-unused-parameter is redundant with -Wextra

Inline trivial version function

Since it only has one call-site.

Rename variable option -> c

This is de-facto a more common name for the return value of getopt.

Remove global input variable

The variable is only used inside the get_choices function. With one
caveat, it can't be freed. No big deal in my opinion since the memory is
accessed through-out the whole execution. Free-ing choices.v[0].string
would not work either since the choices are sorted while searching and
can be reordered.

While at it, favor reallocarray over realloc.

Remove redundant memset of input buffer

The input buffer is never accessed unless it contains anything
considered valid.

Remove bounds check

This condition should always be true. Rather than returning NULL and
silently suppress a potential bug, I would prefer (hopefully) crashing
the program due to a segfault.
Make condition explicit

Use tty as a prefix rather than suffix

In order to gain some consistency regarding function naming.

Fix variable shadowing

The standout variable shadowed a already existing macro defined by
ncurses. While at it, shorten the underline variables, ulso and uleo is
an abbreviation of underline {start,end}-offset. I think the function
provides enough context to make their purpose clear. On the other hand,
the fact I'm documented their meaning in this commit might prove my
assumption wrong.

Fix clear bug

The screen was not cleared when scrolling vertically. Running the
following command and pressing page down would leave a dangling choice
which should no longer be visible:

  printf '1\n2\n3\n' | env LINES=3 pick

The solution is to take the current scroll offset into account.

Add support for page keys

Pressing Page-Down/Page-Up will scroll to next/previous page of choices.
Update year in LICENSE
Add myself as an author
Add a list of package maintainers

Remove remaining release tasks

The remaining release tasks don't work well and for the last couple of
releases I've updated the AUR package manually.

Maintaining distribution specific packages outside of the repo creates a
clear separation of concerns.
Update tests/README

Use one trap

Fixes an issue with running the test-suite on Linux.

Don't require k option in pick-test

Some test-cases omit the keys field but make sure we always pass a valid
keys argument to the parent function since it unconditionally calls
strlen with the given pointer.

Don't disable OXTABS

When compiling on Ubuntu, OXTABS is not defined. SInce we no longer
output any raw tabs, disabling OXTABS output mode is redundant.
Rename pick-test option i -> k for consistency
Adopt style(9) in pick-test

Refactor test.sh and test-case file format

Changes to the test-case file format:

- Turn stdout into a proper field instead of being the last paragraph in
  the test-case file

- Accept multi-line values for stdin and stdout fields

- Rename arguments -> args

- Rename input -> keys

- The exit field must contain the actual exit code. A corresponding
  value of 1 does no longer imply a errorneous exit code.

Changes to test.sh:

- Turn every field in the test-case into a variable. Travsering the
  whole file to access a single field is no longer needed. Running all
  test-cases on my machine is 30% faster by now.

- Assume the command is executed from the root of this repository

- Strict exit code validation

Rename test.c -> pick-test.c

Since test(1) already exists, use a less common command name.
Remove executable mode from test.sh
Remove redundant fields from tests/19.t

Simplify test input handling

Instead of parsing the input given to the test-runner let printf(1) do
the work. This has several advantages: less code and the sequences
defined in get_key can be used without modification in the test-cases.
With one caveat, new-line can't be sent as is since it's a
input-field-separator. Therefore, \\n is used to include a new-line.

Spaces present in the input-field will be ignored unless they are
preceded by a backslash. This makes the test-cases a bit more easier to
read.

Use autoconf log compiler for test suite

Using the log compiler feature of autoconf will run the test runner for
each test-case instead of treating all test-cases as a single test.

Change test file extension

Since the in-extension is used by autoconf it's confusing to use the
same extension for files that are not used by autoconf. The t-extension
is borrowed from the OpenBSD ksh(1) regression-test-suite.
Rename scroll -> xscroll for consistency

Add support for vertical scrolling

Moving beyond the first/last visible choice will now scroll vertically
whenever possible.

The dimensions of the pseudo-tty in by the test-runner is explicitly set
in order to easier deduct when scrolling should happen.

Improve search performance by not wasting cycles

Using pick with a large number of choices is slow. The threshold on my
computer is somewhere around 10k lines of input. Benchmarking the
filtering revealed that the scoring is the bottleneck. This is no
surprise since the current search algorithm is an O(n^2) operation in
worst case. The second most time consuming task is the sorting of the
choices. However, the time taken for qsort(3) is consistent and several
order of magnitude less time consuming than the scoring.

When the user inputs a query longer greater than 1 character we
currently waste lots of cycles by performing a search every time a new
character is received. Even if the current query is outdated since the
user already has typed more character yet to be processed. Therefore,
abort the search if there is unprocessed user input available. This is
done by performing a non-blocking poll(2) call on the user input file
descriptor. The check for new input is done on every 50:th iteration.
The number is empirically chosen and close to the number of lines in my
terminal. There's no guarantee that this number is optimal for everyone.
Experimenting with the number on different computers is therefore of
interest.

This change gives the notion of a responsive interface even when the
input is large. Running the following command prior and after this
change should result in a noticeable speed-up:

  $ find ~ | pick

I think this a decent trade-off in terms of gained performance vs.
complexity.

While at it, remove a cast by changing the type of the local i variable
and replace pre-increment with post-increment.

change the keycode structure in get_key()

- make function get_key() work on big endian machines
- remove inclusion of 'sys/ttydefaults.h'
- remove variable key in get_key()

Fix output of tabs

When a tab is present in the input, output the appropriate number of
spaces. I couldn't achieve the same behavior when the OXTABS output mode
is enabled for some unknown reason.

Remove unused header check

Left-over from 6e9ffc9.
Remove blank line
Sort global variables

Sort function declarations

While at it, break long lines.
Add missing blank line according to style(9)

Add missing description tests

Turn '\n' literals in the output field into proper new lines in order to
match the output when the `-o` option is present.

Inline trivial put_choice function

- Don't use puts for non compile-time constants

- Turn output_description into a local variable

Update Homebrew installation instructions

Since Pick was added to Homebrew core in Homebrew/homebrew-core#1977,
adding the thoughtbot tap before installing with `brew` is no longer
needed.

issue_comments.body:
Great change, and the extracted `memmove()` is a good idea.

Wishlist: `^k`. Actual emacs users don't use `^u` or `^w` but hammer on `^k` all day.
Thanks for the feedback! I will work on this more tomorrow night or on Friday. @mike-burns What does <kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>K</kbd></kbd> do?

<kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>k</kbd></kbd> will delete until the end of line. In actual emacs, to delete a whole line you'd type <kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>a</kbd> <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>u</kbd></kbd>.

(In emacs, <kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>u</kbd></kbd> will add a number in front of a command, so e.g. <kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>u</kbd> <kbd>4</kbd> <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>;</kbd></kbd> will comment out four lines.)
Comments are addressed and <kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>K</kbd></kbd> is implemented. Ready for another pass.
My C's a little rusty, but this looks good to me.
Thanks @georgebrock. Merging.
Me and Jack discussed this IRL and agreed on it being ready to be merged in.
+1 Can reproduce locally in iTerm on OS X
This is awesome @Keithbsmiley! Thanks a lot for figuring this out. Merge at your discretion.

This still appears to be an issue with these steps:
1. Open vim
2. Open your pick search
3. Hit CTRL-C to exit pick without choosing a file
4. Quit vim
Assuming we choose to go this way we may want to add this to the man page as well.

Thanks for reporting this, @Keithbsmiley.

`bsd/string.h` is included for the `strlcpy` function for safely copying strings.

Maybe we could check for the existence of `strlcpy` and include a bundled version if it's not available, like @mike-burns does [in Argonaut](https://github.com/bitptr/argonaut/blob/7377e106c2a855a82f7571a276a38a63dde18724/src/compat.c)?

Running in raw mode will make `ncurses` pass through all characters, including those used for quit, interrupt, suspend and flow control.

Maybe we could use `signal(3)` to trap `SIGINT` to avoid passing through all of them and just handling the interrupt signal?
I had one small comment, other than that, this looks good to merge. Thanks for adding this, @Keithbsmiley!
:+1: got this signal method to work locally. I'll clean it up tomorrow.
Thanks, @Keithbsmiley.
That's what I recommend. I especially recommend using the system library when possible; libbsd does its best to stay up-to-date but your OS gets security patches more often.
This is the other piece of glue, BTW: https://github.com/bitptr/argonaut/blob/master/configure.ac#L6
@calleerlandsson updated with signals.

I can reproduce this locally. This bug did not manifest itself before we added the call to `refresh` in dcc7a8bb52be649cc55a37c9e2b7dee3ab63d2f0. 

Reading `curs_initscr(3X)` it seems like the call to `refresh` after the call to `endwin` might bring us back into curses mode:

```
A program should always call endwin before exiting or escaping from curses mode tem‐
porarily.   This routine restores tty modes, moves the cursor to the lower left-hand
corner of the screen and resets the terminal into the proper non-visual mode.  Call
ing refresh or doupdate after a temporary escape causes the program to resume visual
mode.
```
Looks great @Keithbsmiley, I had some style comments and one question.
@calleerlandsson updated!
Since calling refresh when running in Vim seems to be what we want should we be trying to do that conditionally?
@Keithbsmiley I had one question, other than that, this looks great to merge! Thanks!

This looks good!

The build is currently failing on my system because I don't have the `strlcpy`function in my `string.h`. Therefore, the `strlcpy.c` needs to be conditionally included. One example of how this is done is how `compat/queue.h` gets included in `src/choices.c`.

I have left some comments on how I think it could be fixed. I totally understand if you don't have time to work on this @Keithbsmiley and I can finish this tomorrow.

I think this has to do with the state of the terminal when `pick` gets executed. By having a quick look at `ncurses(3X)`, I think logging the return values of these functions when `pick` starts and ends might tell us more:

```
is_cleared              curs_opaque(3X)*
is_idcok                curs_opaque(3X)*
is_idlok                curs_opaque(3X)*
is_immedok              curs_opaque(3X)*

is_syncok               curs_opaque(3X)*

isendwin                curs_initscr(3X)

I cleaned up a bit the Autotools setup. Using AC_SEARCH_LIBS to detect and link `libncurses` and `libbsd`.

`bsd/string.h` is only included if it exists. (If the plaform already have `strlcpy` and friends without `libbsd` then included that file will led to a `File not found` error.

In some plaforms (Ubuntu 14.04, for example) `freopen` is defined with `__attribute__((warn_unused_result))` so it will raise a warning if the return value of `freopen` is ignored. The current setup is to treat warning as errors so the build break.
I created #16  to fix this problem. Using `AC_SEARCH_LIBS` in the `configure.ac` so that the proper linker flags are generated by the Autotools.

I created pull request #16 which solves this issue and #15. 

The source of the problem is that `freopen` in Ubuntu 14.04 is defined with `__attribute__((warn_unused_result))` so it will generate a warning (I guess that in other platforms it's lacking this attribute). Since warnings are treated as errors , ignoring the return value of `freopen` breaks the build. #16 asserts the the return value is non-null.

```
" pick
function! EscapeFilePath(path)
  return substitute(a:path, ' ', '\\ ', 'g')
endfunction

function! Pick(choice_command, vim_command)
  try
    let selection = system(a:choice_command . " | pick")
  catch /Vim:Interrupt/
    " Swallow the ^C so that the redraw below happens; otherwise there will be
    " UI leftovers on the screen
    redraw!
    return
  endtry
  redraw!
  if strlen(selection) > 0
    exec a:vim_command . " " . EscapeFilePath(selection)
  endif
endfunction

nnoremap <leader>t :call Pick("find * -type f", ":e")<cr>
```

Thanks for reporting this.

I think all examples in the README and on the man page (except the `cd` one in the README) are using `xargs`. I'll keep this in mind when adding more examples, though.

As far as I know there is no way of working around the limitation of `cd` being a shell builtin and the current working directory being a property of the current process. When you run `xargs cd`, your shell will spawn a new `xargs` process that will in turn spawn a new shell process that changes into the directory before exiting. This will not affect the outer shell.

Shift+Enter and Ctrl+Enter sends the same character as Enter. I don't think this is a problem, though. We could actually use the same Enter key binding for this. What we could do to not alter the current functionality of pick, though, is to add a command line flag to turn this feature on.

Adding the flag is done in [`main.c`](https://github.com/thoughtbot/pick/blob/master/src/main.c).

An `int` saying whether or not the flag is present would have to be passed to `get_selected` here: https://github.com/thoughtbot/pick/blob/master/src/main.c#L59

In `ui.c` we could switch on this new `int` parameter: https://github.com/thoughtbot/pick/blob/master/src/ui.c#L243-L247

Since `get_selected` currently returns a pointer to a `struct choice` contained in the passed in `struct choices` we'll either have to figure out:
1. How we could return the current query as a `struct choice`.
2. How we can change `get_selected` to always return a `char *` and then return the current query if the flag is present.

I'd love your feedback on these ideas!

I don't think it should be hidden behind a flag.  The default behavior is still the most useful, which is to select the best-matching result when you hit `enter`.  I think it should just be a separate mapping to use the current input.

It sucks that terminals don't all support `shift+enter` or `ctrl+enter`, as nothing else makes as much sense (vim-wise).  What about `alt+enter` (tested with `^[<cr>` in vim)?  That sequence is sent correctly for me in `urxvt`---does it work in all terminals?

I think it will work if the user is using alt or option as a meta key in their terminal emulator.

This will send two characters to pick: escape followed by enter.

@calleerlandsson Assuming you like the feature addition, there's a decision we need to make before it gets merged in.

There is currently no `break;` statement at the end of the [`TTY_ENTER` case](https://github.com/rosshadden/pick/blob/d3bca6d123805a2314f2abfdfa13f768e2940b7e/src/ui.c#L71-L76).  What this means is that if the user's query has 0 `visible_choices_count`, merely pressing `Enter` (without `Alt`) will use the input query, as execution falls into my `TTY_ALT_ENTER` case.

Said more plainly, it means that typing `blah<Enter>` when there are no matches will output `blah`.

I actually like this behavior a lot, but I'm leaving it up to you to decide if it should be in `pick`.  If you don't, I merely add a `break;` to the end of the preceding case.

Hey @calleerlandsson , I attempt to solve two things with this: matching typos, and excluding a lot of unnecessary noise in the results.

consider a user typing "makefile", the following inputs do match:

~/something/makefile
~/ma/teker/alf/miles_per_hour     <- due to "ma" + "ke" + "f" + "ile"

Often I totally don't need the second of these.
A partial solution would be to only look for exactly matching substring, but that is still not good enough:

Looking for "makefile":

~/something/makefile                    <- found
~/ma/teker/alf/miles_per_hour      <- noise, not matching, as expected
~/something/other/makfile             <- typo, not matching

I would like to find the substring "makfile" as well, which has an edit distance of 1 form the original query "makefile"

Thus looking for substrings with sufficiently low distance from the query:

E.g.: looking for "some/makefile" finds:

~/code/some//makefile            <- not two slashes
~/code/other/some//makfile     <- missing "e" in "makfile"
some makefile                         <-   no slash, but a match anyways
some/makelife                         <-  typo,  makelife vs. makefile

and similar matching strings, while excluding a lot of unnecessary long input lines, that just happen to have the characters in the right order.

I found a workaround for this problem until fish-shell/fish-shell#1362 is solved

``` fish
function scm -d 'Pick and jump into a subdirectory of ~/scm'
  set evalfn /tmp/pick_scm    # define a tmp file to store the pick result
  ls ~/scm | pick >$evalfn    # run pick and store the result
  eval cd ~/scm/(cat $evalfn) # read the content of the file and use it for the cd
  rm $evalfn                  # remove the tmp file afterwards
end
```

Here's what is going on. In Arch Linux, they updated to `ncurses` 6, as implied by my above post.  This means it's a breaking change for things explicitly looking for `/usr/lib/libncursesw.so.5`.

I "solved" this by installing an `ncurses5` package alongside my main `ncurses` package, however the best solution would be for `pick` to instead use `/usr/lib/libncursesw.so`.  On most systems this should be a symlink to the current `ncurses`, in my case `6`.

I don't see in the code where this reference is made, so I don't know where to change it.  You guys are possibly using a library or wrapper around `ncurses` which is doing this.  If so let me know and I will open an issue there.

Yeap, it builds (it's also a [patch](https://github.com/eavgerinos/pkg-pick/blob/master/debian/patches/ncursesw-compatibility) I included in the debian package).

The [`AC_TRY_LINK`](http://ftp.gnu.org/old-gnu/Manuals/autoconf-2.53/html_node/Examining-Libraries.html) defines the `HAVE_NCURSESW_H` hdef.

On the other hand [`AC_SEARCH_LIBS`](https://www.gnu.org/software/autoconf/manual/autoconf-2.69/html_node/Libraries.html) iterates through a list of alternative choices in order to tell if at least 1 of the alternatives is available on the system.

So, imho, we need `AC_TRY_LINK`

Should `separators` be singular `separator`?

Given that `$IFS` is actually a list of possible field separating characters, I think `separators` is a better name for what it is. In case you weren’t aware of this behavior, this is exactly how `strtok_r` works too, so there should be no regression. `strtok_r` [uses](https://github.molgen.mpg.de/git-mirror/glibc/blob/master/string/strtok_r.c#L63) `strpbrk` internally, while `strpbrk` is [implemented via two loops](https://github.molgen.mpg.de/git-mirror/glibc/blob/master/string/strpbrk.c) with the outer loop iterating a given string char-by-char and the inner one checking these characters for inclusion in separators.

Default `$IFS` set by Bash includes all regular whitespace characters (space, tab and newline):

``` bash
$ echo "$IFS" | cat -te
 ^I$
$
```
That makes a lot of sense. Thanks for explaining it! Should we rename `field_separator` to `field_separators` or `separators` for parity?

OpenBSD's reallocarray(3) says:

> Do not adjust the variable describing how much memory has been allocated until the allocation has been successful. This can cause aberrant program behavior if the incorrect size value is used. In most cases, the above sample will also result in a leak of memory. As stated earlier, a return value of NULL indicates that the old object still remains allocated.

http://www.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/man.cgi/OpenBSD-current/man3/calloc.3

They show this with `realloc` but then later with `reallocarray`.
Passing `NULL` as the second argument to err(3) will print a default message, which (should, hopefully) include the text "reallocarray".

>

> static char   *function(int, const char *); 
> static void    usage(void);
> ```

As far as I understand, we only want to do this when the query is changed or put differently; whenever we do the following:

```
filter_choices();
selection = 0;
```

Reading through the code, I notice this bit being duplicated in all cases where the query is changed.

In all other cases we also want to skip resetting `yscroll`. For example, in the left and right arrow key cases. Currently after advancing `yscroll`, pressing left or right arrow will reset it to `0`.

I see two possible solutions to this:
- We could add `yscroll = 0;` wherever the above bit is duplicated. This would introduce more duplication but would fix the bug.
- Alternatively, we could extract the call to `filter_choices` and resetting the `selection` to just above this line and add `continue` statements to all branches that shouldn't go through the reset.

appropriate. See ab2fe6f.

What do you think about letting the page up/down keys also control the selection by advancing it by a `lines` number of choices and then scrolling the choices to show the selection?

If `selection < lines` then it could `selection = 0` and when `choices_count - selection < lines` then it could `selection = choices_count`.

Great input! I agree, the current behaviour is confusing. I followed
your advice and made the page down/up move the selection one page
down/up, counting from the current selection. If less choices than a
full page is available the first/last choice is selected. The man-page
is updated, do you think it describes the behaviour clear enough?
The new behavior works great and the description sounds good!

I agree that zeroing out the input buffer isn't necessary. Thanks for catching that!

I'm not sure how the change to this condition is related to this. Could you elaborate on this? When is `length` zero?
Since we're only ever freeing this at the end of successful execution, I agree that letting the OS do this is fine.

I can't really tell the difference between `tty_lines` and `lines` just from this name.

Would something like `choice_lines` make it clearer that it is `lines` minus 1 for the query line?
Great catch!
You're right, `length` will never be zero. Fixed in 02e4a4c.
Great proposal, fixed in f52c184.

This will break on Big Endian machines. Since `c` is declared as an `int` the read byte will end up in the Most-Significant-Byte (`c & 0xff000000`). The remaning bytes of `c` will be filled with potential garbage from stack since `c` is not initialized. Reading uninitialized memory from the stack is in addition undefined behavior. `c` should therefore be declared as `char` and preferably `unsigned char`. Note that this is only important when passing the argument to `read(3)`. The variable can then safely be promoted to a larger type such as `int`.

Prior to release, I always run the tests on an old Mac with a 32-bit PPC processor.
Don't see the point of a pointer-pointer (no pun intended!). Probably due to copy-pasting the prototype for `get_key`.
I would rather see the bindings being defined inside `get_key` and adding a field to the struct indicating that some bindings are only applicable to Vi-mode.
Same reasoning as above regarding the type of `c`.
I would prefer `-1` instead of `ERR` for consistency with the rest of the code. Also, continuing reading on `errno == EINTR` would be a good addition.
